screens.headline: ASSIGNED: You bought 100 shares. Now what?
screens.text: Getting assigned on a CSP terrifies beginners. But it's not a disaster - it's part of the strategy! In 7 minutes, you'll learn how to handle assignment like a pro and even profit from it.

screens.headline: Assignment is NOT a Punishment
screens.text: When you sell a put, assignment means you're OBLIGATED to buy 100 shares at the strike price. This happens when the stock drops below your strike at expiration. You already collected premium, so your effective cost is lower than the strike. You bought the stock you wanted - just at a discount!

screens.headline: Think of it like a limit order that pays YOU
screens.text: You want to buy a TV on sale for $800 or less. Regular strategy: Set a $800 limit order and wait (no pay). CSP strategy: Someone pays you $50 to PROMISE you'll buy at $800 if it goes on sale. Black Friday arrives, TV drops to $750. You buy at $800 (your 'limit') but got paid $50 to wait = effective cost $750. If TV never goes on sale? You keep the $50 and try again.

reveal_sections.label: Black Friday = Stock drops below strike
You buy the TV = Assignment (buy 100 shares)

cards.example: Assigned at $360, market $340 = -$2,000 unrealized loss (for now)

screens.question: You sold a $100 put for $3 premium. Stock drops to $90 at expiration. What's your assignment price and effective cost?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! You buy at $100 (strike price) but collected $3 premium = $97 effective cost. Current market is $90, so you're $7/share underwater ($700 total). But you wanted this stock anyway - and you got in $3 cheaper than just buying at $100!
screens.explanation_wrong: Remember: Assignment ALWAYS happens at the STRIKE PRICE ($100), not market price ($90). But you keep the $3 premium, so your effective cost is $97.

screens.question: Assigned at $150 strike, stock now $130. You're down $2,000. What should you do?
options: Panic sell immediately at $130 to stop the bleeding
Hold the stock - you wanted it anyway at $150
Sell a covered call on your new shares to collect more premium
Either B or C depending on your outlook
screens.explanation_correct: Excellent thinking! If still bullish, HOLD (you wanted it at $150, now it's 'on sale' at $130!). If neutral, SELL A COVERED CALL to collect premium and reduce cost basis further. Only panic sellers choose A - don't be one!
screens.explanation_wrong: Think strategically: You wanted this stock at $150. Now it's $130. If your thesis hasn't changed, this is a BETTER entry. Plus you can now sell covered calls to collect even MORE premium. Don't panic!

screens.description: See what happens after assignment in different market conditions

strategy_suggestions.if_down_small: Stock $350-355: Down <2%. HOLD or sell covered call at $365+ to collect more premium.
strategy_suggestions.if_down_medium: Stock $340-350: Down 2-5%. Sell ATM covered call ($340-345) for max premium to recover faster.
strategy_suggestions.if_down_large: Stock $300-340: Down >5%. Hold if thesis intact. Consider selling far OTM calls ($370+) to not cap recovery.

teaching_points: Try $355: Breaking even - hold and sell covered call
Try $340: 4% down - not disaster, be patient
Try $320: 10% down - reevaluate your stock pick

cards.back: NO! You bought a stock you WANTED at the price you CHOSE. The premium reduced your cost. Getting assigned is the PLAN, not a failure.
HOLD if thesis intact. Stock was worth $360 to you, now it's cheaper! OR sell covered calls to collect premium and reduce cost basis.
Sell far OTM puts (10%+ below stock price). Lower premium but much safer. Or close the put early if stock is dropping.
